affiliations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research

children.value: In this tutorial we will present an interface under design to facilitate complex searching using
package under development in ESGF2. Please note that there is a name collison with an existing package in PyPI and conda. You will need to install the package from

import intake_esgf
from intake_esgf import ESGFCatalog

we first instantiate the catalog. However, since we will populate the catalog with search results, the catalog starts empty. Internally, we query different ESGF index nodes for information about what datasets you wish to include in your analysis. As ESGF2 is actively working on an index redesign, our catlogs by default point to a Globus (ElasticSearch) based index at ALCF (Argonne Leadership Computing Facility).

cat = ESGFCatalog()
print(cat)
for ind in cat.indices: # Which indices are included?
    print(ind)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
Perform a search() to populate the catalog.
GlobusESGFIndex('ESGF2-US-1.5-Catalog')

children.value: We also provide support for connecting to the ESGF1 Solr-based indices. You may specify a server in the dictionary or multiple servers - just make sure to include

intake_esgf.conf.set(indices={"esgf-node.llnl.gov": True,
                              "esgf-node.ornl.gov": True,
                              "esgf.ceda.ac.uk": True})

intake_esgf.conf.set(all_indices=True)  # all federated indices

cat = ESGFCatalog()
for ind in cat.indices:
    print(ind)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
GlobusESGFIndex('ESGF2-US-1.5-Catalog')
GlobusESGFIndex('anl-dev')
GlobusESGFIndex('ornl-dev')
SolrESGFIndex('esgf.ceda.ac.uk')
SolrESGFIndex('esgf-data.dkrz.de')
SolrESGFIndex('esgf-node.ipsl.upmc.fr')
SolrESGFIndex('esg-dn1.nsc.liu.se')
SolrESGFIndex('esgf.nci.org.au')
SolrESGFIndex('esgf-node.ornl.gov')
SolrESGFIndex('esgf-node.llnl.gov')

children.value: Many times, an analysis will require several variables across multiple experiments. For example, if one were to compute the transient climate response (TCRE), you would need tempererature (
) as well as the control experiment (

). If TCRE is not in your particular science, that is ok for this notebook. It is a motivating example and the specifics are less important than the search concepts. First, we perform a search in a familiar syntax.

children.value: Internally, this launches simultaneous searches that are combined locally to provide a global view of what datasets are available. While the Solr indices themselves can be searched in distributed fashion, they will not report if an index has failed to return a response. As index nodes go down from time to time, this can leave you with a false impression that you have found all the datasets of interest. By managing the searches locally,
can report back to you that an index has failed and that your results may be incomplete.
If you would like details about what
is doing, look in the local cache directory (
file. This is a full history of everything that
has searched, downloaded, or accessed. You can also look at just this session by calling
. In this case you will see how long each index took to return a response and if any failed

children.value: At this stage of the search you have a catalog full of possibly relevant datasets for your analysis, stored in a
dataframe. You are free to view and manipulate this dataframe to help hone these results down. It is available to you as the
. You should be careful to only remove rows as internally we could use any column in the downloading of the data. Also note that we have removed the user-facing notion of
column of this dataframe is a list of full
which includes the location information. At the point when you are ready to download data, we will choose locations automatically that are fastest for you.

children.value: also provides you with some tools to help locate relevant data for your analysis. When conducting these kinds of analyses, we are seeking for unique combinations of a
that have all the variables that we need. We call these
. In an ESGF search, it is common to find a model that has, for example, a
. Sorting this out is time consuming and labor intensive. So first, we provide you a function to print out all model groups with the following function.

ACCESS-ESM1-5   r1i1p1f1  gn                6

AWI-ESM-1-1-LR  r1i1p1f1  gn                2

151 rows × 1 columns

children.value: returns a pandas Series (converted to a dataframe here for printing) with all unique combinations of (

) along with the dataset count for each. This helps illustrate why it can be so difficult to locate all the data relevant to a given analysis. At the time of this writing, there are 148 model groups but relatively few of them with all 6 (2 experiments and 3 variables) datasets that we need. Furthermore, you cannot rely on a model group using
for its primary result. The results above show that UKESM does not even use
at all, further complicating the process of finding results.
In addition to this notion of

for determing which model groups you wish to keep in the current search. Internally, we will group the search results dataframe by model groups and apply a function of your design to the grouped portion of the dataframe. For example, for the current work, I could just check that there are 6 datasets in the sub-dataframe.

children.value: You could write a much more complex check--it depends on what is relevant to your analysis. The effect is that the list of possible models with consistent results is now much more manageable. This method has the added benefit of forcing the user to be concrete about which models were included in an analysis.
It may also be that you wish to only include a single
in your analysis. The above search shows we have a few models with multiple variants that have all 6 required datasets. To be fair to those that only have 1, you may wish to only keep the
variant. We also provide this function as part of the

children.value: At this point, you would be ready to use

to download and load all datasets into a dictionary for analysis. The point of this notebook however is to expose the search capabilities. It is our goal to make annoying and time-consuming tasks easier by providing you smart interfaces for common operations. Let us
what else is painful for you in locating relevant data for your science.

Gregory_2008.label: Gregory_2008
Gregory_2008.html: Gregory, J. M., & Forster, P. M. (2008). Transient climate response estimated from radiative forcing and observed temperature change. Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, 113(D23). 10.1029/2008jd010405
